p: Throughout December 2019, numerous cases of “pneumonia of unknown origin” were reported throughout Wuhan, China. By January 7, 2020, next-generation sequencing revealed that the pathogen was a novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), within the B etacoronavirus genus. Further analysis revealed that this 2019-nCoV had similarities in its receptor-binding domain (RBD) and conserved replicase sequence with SARS-CoV-1, suggesting that they were in the same subgenera ( Sarbecovirus) [ 3- 6]. These similarities in structure were used to classify the 2019 n-CoV as SARS-CoV-2.
